description: Canada, Quebec, March 13 "Gatherings of more than 250 indoors are prohibited for the next 10 days"

In Canada on March 12th, the province of Alberta is asking organizers to cancel any events that have more than 250 attendees. This includes large sporting events, conferences and community events. It does not extend to places of worship, grocery stores, airports or shopping centres.

Any event that has more than 50 attendees and expects to have international participants, or involves critical infrastructure staff, seniors, or other high-risk populations should also be cancelled.
Events that do not meet these criteria can proceed, but risk mitigation must be in place, such as sanitizer stations and distancing between attendees.

Canada, NB, March 12 "the Office of the Chief Medical Officer of Health recommends that any non-essential mass gathering (150 or more people) be cancelled or postponed until we are able to better determine the risk to our population."

The Government of Alberta in Canada stated on March 13th that "given recent recommendations from Alberta’s chief medical officer of health, we feel it is in the best interest of prospective visitors, staff and volunteers to implement temporary facility access restrictions at some Alberta Parks sites."

Canada, Manitoba, March 13, "Public health officials continue to recommend social distancing measures for all Manitobans, such as cancelling or postponing any large-scale events with more than 250 attendees"

Canada, Ont, March 13 "To help contain the spread of COVID-19, Dr. David Williams, Ontario's Chief Medical Officer of Health, has recommended the immediate suspension of all gatherings over 250 people because of this pandemic."

Canada, British Columbia March 16th "We are issuing a new order prohibiting all public gatherings of more than 50 people. This includes indoor and outdoor sporting events, conferences, meetings, religious gatherings and other similar events. "
Canada, Yukon, March 16 "Mass gatherings of more than 50 people are banned."

Canada, SK, March 13 "Effective March 16th The Chief Medical Health Officer orders that no public gathering of over 250 people in any one room takes place.  This does not include settings where people are distributed into multiple rooms or buildings, such as schools, universities or workplaces."

Canada, Ont, March 16 "I am strongly recommending a further limitation to public gatherings from my advice on March 12, 2020. I am further advising Ontarians to avoid large gatherings of over 50 people" UPDATE: Recommended gatherings of 250 or less, now an order for 50 or less

Canada, Sask, March 16 "Faith based organizations are no longer exempt to public gathering restrictions ordering that no public gathering of over 250 people in any one room take place." UPDATE: Restrictions extended to faith based organisations
Canada, NS, March 17 "Effectively immediately, there are to be no gatherings of more than 50 people."

In the Province of Alberta in Canada, as of March 17th, mass gatherings are now limited to no more than 50 attendees. This includes worship gatherings and family events such as weddings. Grocery stores, shopping centres, health-care facilities, airports, and other essential services are not included. UPDATE: Mass Gatherings now limited from 250 to 50 attendees

In Alberta Canada as of March 17th "Ski hills across the province are strongly encouraged to close by the end of day March 17, to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
Effective March 18, all passenger ropeways, like gondolas and chairlifts, will be closed until further notice under the Safety Codes Act.
All provincial historic sites and the Provincial Archives will be closing March 17. Information regarding facility bookings and passes will be available on the facilities’ websites." UPDATE: More closures for provincial parks, as well as ski hills and passenger ropeways, chairlifts and gondolas

Canada, NS, March 17 "Effectively immediately, there are to be no gatherings of more than 50 people." UPDATE: Gathering limits have been relaxed in Nova scotia, Canada as of June 18th. 

People can now gather in groups of up to 10 without physical distancing. People in a group are not required to be exclusive but they are strongly encouraged to maintain a consistent group. This is especially important for Nova Scotians who are more at risk of complications from COVID-19. This change replaces the concept of family household bubbles.

Gatherings of up to 50 will now be allowed but people must observe physical distancing of two metres or six feet.

The larger gathering limit of 50 applies to social events, faith gatherings, sports and physical activity, weddings and funerals, and arts and culture events like theatre performances, dance recitals, festivals and concerts.
Canada, NL, March 18th "Ban of public gatherings greater than 50 people prohibited"
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Canada, Yukon, March 18 "All public indoor recreational facilities are required to close until further notice. This includes the Canada Games Centre, ice rinks and recreation centres. Additionally, all libraries are closed until further notice"
Canada, Sask, March 18 "Public gatherings larger than 50 people are prohibited." UPDATE: Gatherings limited from 250 to 50

Canada, Sask, March 20 "Public gatherings of more than 25 people in one room are prohibited except where two metre distancing between people can be maintained; workplace and meeting settings where people are distributed into multiple rooms or buildings; and retail locations (ie. grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations)." UPDATE: Restriction of gathering from less than 50 to less than 25 people

Canada, NB, March 19 "Owners and operators of all other premises at which people may gather in large numbers will take all reasonable steps to prevent gatherings of more than 10 people." UPDATE: Gatherings now limited to no greater than 5 from 150

Canada, NB, April 8 "Religious gatherings restricted during state of emergency. Residents are reminded that as part of the state of emergency for COVID-19, restrictions are in place for all gatherings, including religious celebrations." UPDATE: A reminder that the limitation of gatherings also applies to religious gatherings

Canada, NB, April 8 "Religious gatherings restricted during state of emergency. Residents are reminded that as part of the state of emergency for COVID-19, restrictions are in place for all gatherings, including religious celebrations."
Canada, Manitoba, March 20 "recommending the cancellation of gatherings of more than 50 people" UPDATE: Events from 250 now restricted to be less than 50 people
Canada, Quebec, March 20 "all indoor and outdoor assemblies are prohibited" UPDATE: Full restriction on indoor/outdoor gatherings

Canada, Sask, March 20 "Public gatherings of more than 25 people in one room are prohibited except where two metre distancing between people can be maintained; workplace and meeting settings where people are distributed into multiple rooms or buildings; and retail locations (ie. grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations)." UPDATE: Restriction of gathering from less than 50 to less than 25 people

Canada, Sask, March 25 "To reduce the spread of COVID-19, the Government of Saskatchewan is limiting the size of public and private gatherings to a maximum of ten people. " UPDATE: Restriction from gatherings of 25 to 10 or less

Canada, Manitoba, March 21, "issuing public health orders to:
 limit public gathering to less than 50 people including places of worship, family event, wedding and funerals; and limit hospitality premises such as restaurants or theatres to 50 people or 50 per cent of
capacity (whichever is less)" UPDATE: No longer a recommendation but an order.

Canada, NS, March 22 "effective immediately, provincial parks, beaches and tourist attractions are closed. Provincial trails will remain open for exercise. Gathering limits and social distancing guidelines must be followed"

Canada, NS, March 22 "New orders in effect under the Health Protection Act include: effective immediately, social gatherings of more than five people are prohibited" UPDATE: Gatherings diminished from 50 to maximum 5

Canada, Yukon, March 22 "Gatherings of more than 10 people are banned. Smaller gatherings should ensure spacing of two metres between people. Yukoners should not attend any social gatherings, even those with less than 10 people if:
You have any flu-like symptoms at all;
You are over 65 years of age or have an underlying health condition; or
You work in healthcare, a healthcare facility or other essential services." UPDATE: Mass gatherings banned, was 50 but now down to 10 or less

Canada, Yukon, March 22 "Gatherings of more than 10 people are banned. Smaller gatherings should ensure spacing of two metres between people. Yukoners should not attend any social gatherings, even those with less than 10 people if:
You have any flu-like symptoms at all;
You are over 65 years of age or have an underlying health condition; or
You work in healthcare, a healthcare facility or other essential services."
Canada, Nunavut, March 23 "All gatherings greater than 5 persons are prohibited. Additionally, all persons must maintain a 2-meter physical distance between one another. "
Canada, Quebec, March 23 "Quebec bans gatherings of 2 or more" UPDATE: Gatherings of 2 or more people banned

Canada, BC, March 24, "BC Parks closures, the Recreation Sites and Trails BC (RSTBC) branch of the Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development is closing its campgrounds and amenities in response to the COVID-19 situation."

Canada, Sask, March 25 "To reduce the spread of COVID-19, the Government of Saskatchewan is limiting the size of public and private gatherings to a maximum of ten people. " UPDATE: Restriction from gatherings of 25 to 10 or less

In Alberta, Canada, as of March 27th "people are prohibited from attending gatherings of more than 15, and they must observe two metres of social distancing. This includes:
open spaces such as trails, fields and parks
public and private gatherings where people are brought together in a single room or space at the same time, including funerals, weddings and other formal and informal events" UPDATE: This is an update (of an update) of the restriction of mass gatherings from 50 to 15

description: Canada, Ont, March 28 "Based on the best advice of Ontario's Chief Medical Officer of Health, the Ontario government is issuing a new emergency order under the Emergency Management and Civil Protection Act to prohibit organized public events and social gatherings of more than five people, effective immediately." UPDATE: Gatherings limited now from 50 to less than 5

Canada, Manitoba, March 27 "Public gatherings will be limited to no more than 10 people at any indoor or outdoor place or premises.  This includes places of worship, gatherings and family events such as weddings and funerals.  This does not apply to a facility where health care or social services are provided including child-care centres and homeless shelters. " UPDATE: Gatherings were allowed up to 50 but not restricted to 10 or less

Canada, Ont, March 30 "Ontario is issuing a new emergency order under the Emergency Management and Civil Protection Act to close all outdoor recreational amenities, such as sports fields and playgrounds, effective immediately" UPDATE: More closures to restrict gatherings

Canada, NB, April 2nd "Campgrounds and other social venues will remain closed until further notice, in keeping with the revised and renewed state of emergency mandatory order on COVID-19 issued today by the provincial government."

Canada, NB, April 3 "All provincial parks as well as playgrounds provincewide are closed.

Higgs said today that if municipalities are going to keep their parks and trails open, they must have mechanisms in place to ensure that the limitations on the number of people that can gather is enforced."

Canada, P.E.I., April 3 "Islanders gathering in groups of more than five people could be issued heavy fines for failing to comply with the province's new COVID-19 public health order.
People gathering in groups of more than five people will see fines if they are in places where a two-metre distance isn't possible."
Alberta, Canada - April 4, 2020. Public Health Order on all citizens restricting indoor and outdoor public gatherings and private gatherings of over 10 people.

Canada, NWT, April 10 "For our purposes, a gathering is when any amount of people get together in the same indoor
space who don’t live in the same household.
Getting together outdoors is allowed for up to 10 people if social (physical) distance of at least
two metres is maintained the entire time."

Canada, Ontario, April 11 "To help stop the spread of COVID-19 and protect the health and safety of people across the province, the Ontario government has extended all emergency orders that have been put in place to-date under s.7.0.2 (4) of the Emergency Management and Civil Protection Act until April 23, 2020, including the closure of outdoor amenities in parks and recreational areas" UPDATE: Extension of the policy
Canada, Québec- As of the 23 April "the cancellation of indoor and outdoor festivals and cultural events," including sporting events, "planned in Québec until August 31, 2020."

This extension will help protect the health and well-being of people across the province and stop the spread of COVID-19.

This Emergency Order extension includes the closure of outdoor amenities in parks and recreational areas" UPDATE: Extension of the closure of recreational areas/parks

Canada, NB, April 24 "As an alternative to online worship, religious organizations can hold outdoor services if parishioners stay in their vehicles that are two metres apart." UPDATE: While religious gatherings are still generally cancelled, as an alternative to online worship, religious organizations can hold outdoor services if parishioners stay in their vehicles that are two metres apart.

Canada, Ontario, April 25 ""In order to keep Ontarians safe during this COVID-19 outbreak, our government is extending the closure of Ontario's provincial parks and conservation reserves to May 31, 2020. This includes car camping, backcountry camping, roofed accommodations, day use opportunities, access points and all public buildings.
Provincial parks and conservation reserves will continue to remain fully closed to all recreational activities.
Reservations for arrivals up to, and including, any further closure extension date will be automatically cancelled and reservation holders will receive a full refund with no penalty. We are also providing penalty-free refunds to reservation holders who wish to change or cancel their 2020 camping reservation, regardless of arrival date." UPDATE: extension of park closures from April 30 until May 31 (extension of 1 month)

Canada, PEI, April 28 "Beginning May 1, outdoor gatherings and non-contact outdoor recreational activities of no more than five individuals from different households, while maintaining physical distancing, will be permitted. This includes recreational fishing, golf courses and current PEI residents going to their own seasonal properties." UPDATE: the policy is being relaxed slightly

Canada, Nova Scotia, May 1 "provincial and municipal parks can reopen, but playground equipment will continue to be off-limits. Additionally, 
trails are allowed to open" UPDATE: Provincial parks are now open
Canada, Alberta, May 1 "Provincial parks are now open for day use. Parking lots and staging areas on public land are now open" UPDATE: As of May 1st, provincial parks may now open

Canada, NB, May 8th "As of today, campgrounds and outdoor recreational activities, such as zoos and outfitters may open, subject to maintaining physical distancing measures, general guidelines from Public Health and the Guidelines for New Brunswick Workplaces issued by WorkSafe NB." UPDATE: As of May 8th, Campgrounds and outdoor recreational activities may open

Canada, NB, May 8 "Originally mass gatherings of 150 or more were banned, then on March 19th, gatherings were limited to 10 persons or less. On April 24th, the government reminded people that religious gatherings needed to be of 10 persons of less and done outside. 

As of May 8th, outdoor public gatherings, with physical distancing, of 10 or fewer people are allowed. And indoor public gatherings, with physical distancing, of 10 or fewer people for in-person religious services, weddings and funerals. UPDATE: Change to the restriction of gatherings in indoor and outdoor spaces

Canada, P.E.I., May 8th "April 3 gathering of more than five people banned. This was relaxed on April 28 where outdoor gatherings and non-contact outdoor recreational activities of no more than five individuals from different households, while maintaining physical distancing, will be permitted. As of May 8th, members of the same household may gather indoors with up to 5 other individuals from different households.
Members of the same household may gather outdoors with up to 10 other individuals from different households." UPDATE: Restriction of indoor and outdoor gatherings is being relaxed slightly

Canada, PEI, April 28, "Beginning May 1, outdoor gatherings and non-contact outdoor recreational activities of no more than five individuals from different households, while maintaining physical distancing, will be permitted. This includes recreational fishing, golf courses and current PEI residents going to their own seasonal properties."

These policies are under Phase 1 of the reopening of PEI.

Canada, NL, May 10  "On March 18th, public gatherings greater than 50 people were prohibited. On April 16th, gatherings greater than 5 were prohibited. Now, starting May 11th, gatherings for funerals, burials and weddings are expanded to 10 people, as long as physical distancing can be maintained. Visitation and wakes remain prohibited." UPDATE: The prohibition of gatherings was 5, and is now 10 as of May 11th
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
Canada, Ont, May 9th "On March 18th all provincial parks will be closed 
The Ontario government is opening provincial parks and conservation reserves for limited day-use access. This closure was extended on April 25th. 
The Ontario government is opening provincial parks and conservation reserves for limited day-use access. The first areas will open on Monday May 11, 2020, with the remaining areas opening on Friday May 15, 2020. At this time, recreational activities will be limited to walking, hiking, biking and birdwatching. Day visitors will also be able to access all parks and conservation reserves for free until the end of the month. "

Canada, NB, May 12 "Provincial parks and attractions will reopen with limited services, no events, and no programming or co-ordinated activities." UPDATE: Provincial parks and attractions will reopen with limited services, no events, and no programming or co-ordinated activities.

Canada, Alberta, May 15 "gatherings of persons in excess of 50 people, in an outdoor location, is prohibited"

 UPDATE: The original restriction of mass gatherings restricted 15 or more persons from gathering, this restriction is being relaxed to be 50 or more persons in a gathering being restricted.

description: Canada, Québec- As of the 23 April "the cancellation of indoor and outdoor festivals and cultural events planned in Québec until August 31, 2020." UPDATE: Beginning May 20, "non-contact sports, leisure, and outdoor activities throughout the province"

description: Canada, Manitoba, May 20 "As of Friday, May 22 public health orders will be modified to increase the limit on gathering size to no more than 25 people for indoor premises and 50 for outdoor areas, providing social distancing measures are in place." UPDATE: The restriction on mass gatherings both indoor and outdoor are relaxing slightly
Canada, Quebec, May 22 "Persons can be assembled for a maximum of 10 people." UPDATE: Gatherings of maximum 10 are now allowed

Canada, P.E.I., "Limited indoor gatherings of no more than 5 individuals and outdoor gatherings of no more  than 10 individuals involving people from different households" starting May 22. UPDATE: The original policy only let parties under 5 people gather outside, but it has been relaxed to 5 indoor and 10 outside.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)

description: Canada, B.C. announced on May 29 that no person may operate an overnight camp for children and youth.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description: Canada, NS, May 29 "Premier Stephen McNeil and Dr. Robert Strang, chief medical officer of health for Nova Scotia, announced today, May 29, a new gathering limit of 10 and more steps toward reopening the province." UPDATE: Restriction of Gatherings now limited to 10 persons instead of 5

Canada, Ontario closure of overnight camping at all places other than Crown land and Ontario Parks "and some day-use activities at provincial parks and conservation reserves has been extended to June 14 and will continue to be reassessed." UPDATE: The original closure of parks was set to be April 30, 2020 and was updated several times -- it is now updated to close until June 14.

Canada, Nunavut, May 25 "The size limit for outdoor gatherings will increase to 25 people, from 5" UPDATE: The restriction of mass gathering is being relaxed from gatherings of no more than 5 being prohibited, to gathering of no more than 25 being prohibited.

Canada, Ontario "is gradually reintroducing camping in Ontario Parks and recreational camping on Crown land, starting June 1, 2020"
These activities include "backcountry camping will be available at Ontario Parks, including access points, paddle and portage routes and hiking trails. Ontario Parks will also be expanding day-use activities to include picnicking and off-leash pet areas."

"no more than five people will be allowed to occupy a backcountry campsite during their stay, unless they live in the same household." UPDATE: Provincial parks are gradually reopening

Canada, P.E.I., is allowing gatherings "of no more than 15 people indoor, and 20 people outdoors"

Additionally, "singing, wind and/or brass instruments are permitted provided singers/vocalists, wind and brass players are a minimum of 3.5 metres (12 feet) apart from each other and everyone else.
Vigorous vocalization should also be avoided when closer than 3.5 metres (12 feet) distance from other individuals (e.g. shouting, cheering)." UPDATE: The social gathering limit has been relaxed to 15-20 people.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)

description: Canada, PEI, "Indoor dining and service at food premises, breweries, cideries and wineries permitted; 50 persons permitted inside, with additional persons permitted on patio; no buffet style" UPDATE: Indoor dining is now allowed up to 50 persons

Canada, PEI "Dental will begin scheduling elective treatment with priority on urgent and emergency care.
Expansion of elective dental procedures and return of hygienists to practice.
Continued transition to increased non-urgent health services." starting June 1 as part of the Phase 3 reopening. UPDATE: Dental clinics are allowed to resume some services starting June 1.

Canada, NB, June 5th "As of June 5th: Indoor gatherings in private homes of 10 people or fewer are permitted. Outdoor public gatherings of 50 people or fewer will be permitted with physical distancing.
And Religious services, including wedding and funerals, of 50 people or fewer may take place indoors or outdoors with physical distancing." UPDATE: Relaxation of restriction on indoor and outdoor gatherings

Day camps across Nova Scotia can reopen provided they have a plan in place to address public health measures.

Dr. Robert Strang, chief medical officer of health, released COVID-19 guidelines all summer day camps must follow, today, June 12.

Based on these guidelines, all day camp operators must have an individual plan in place to support reopening. Plans will cover key areas such as:

increased cleaning
staggered pick up and drop off times
screening staff and campers
limiting group sizes to 10, keeping the same groups of children together
multiple groups are allowed but they must be kept separated
increased hand washing and minimizing sharing of equipment
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions

description: Canada, Ontario, "will increase the limit on social gatherings from five to 10 people across the province, regardless of whether a region has moved to Stage 2" starting Friday, June 12, 2020.

Canada, June 12 "Maximum 50 people: Indoor social gatherings – including wedding and funeral receptions, and birthday parties
Maximum 100 people: Outdoor events and indoor seated/audience events – including wedding and funeral ceremonies
No cap on the number of people (with public health measures and physical distancing in place): Worship gatherings, Restaurants, cafés, lounges and bars,  Casinos, and Bingo halls"

 UPDATE: The policy is changing and allowing larger gatherings

UPDATE: The original policy stated that places of fellowship were closed, but they are now able to reopen with specific restrictions on attendance.

Canada, Ont, April 23 " On the advice of the Chief Medical Officer of Health, the Ontario government is extending all emergency orders that have been put in place to-date under s.7.0.2 (4) of the Emergency Management and Civil Protection Act until May 6, 2020. This extension will help protect the health and well-being of people across the province and stop the spread of COVID-19.

This Emergency Order extension includes the closure of outdoor amenities in parks and recreational areas" UPDATE: Extension of the closure of recreational areas/parks

Canada, Québec: "indoor and outdoor gatherings of up to 50 people are allowed in some public places. As in other circumstances, a distance of 2 metres between people is required." UPDATE: The original restriction on gatherings did not allow more than 250 people in an indoor gathering, it has been updated to where "indoor and outdoor gatherings of up to 50 people are allowed in some public places."

Canada, Manitoba, March 13, "Public health officials continue to recommend social distancing measures for all Manitobans, such as cancelling or postponing any large-scale events with more than 250 attendees" UPDATE: Key changes made following public feedback include:
• removing the maximum capacity of 300 people at any site provided the gathering can be physically divided into sub-groups of 50 or fewer indoors or 100 or fewer outdoors, to a maximum 30 per cent of usual capacity

• lifting capacity limits for restaurants, bars, beverage rooms, brew pubs, microbreweries and distilleries, as long as tables and seating are arranged so there is a temporary or physical barrier, or two metres of separation between people sitting at different tables.

Visitors to museums will be required to practise physical distancing and follow the site-specific guidelines to ensure a safe environment for all." UPDATE: Some museeums are now opening.

Canada, PEI, "Larger organized gatherings such as sports and recreation, day camps, weddings, funerals, burials and worship services are allowed with no more than 50 people indoor or outdoor" as of June 24 as part of Phase 4 reopening. UPDATE: The limit for gatherings such as funerals has been increased to 50 people.

description:
The following are allowed at the Yellow level:

Household bubbles can be extended to close friends and family.
Outdoor gatherings in uncontrolled venues with distancing of 50 or fewer people.
A cap on the number of people gathering in controlled venues is lifted. Occupancy is based on the ability to maintain physical distancing between participants that are not close friends and family. This includes churches, swimming pools, saunas, waterparks, rinks, indoor recreational facilities and organized sports which previously had a gathering limit of 50 people.

Canada, NB, April 8 "Religious gatherings restricted during state of emergency. UPDATE: A reminder that the limitation of gatherings also applies to religious gatherings

description:
In Canada on June 30th, the province of Alberta Annouced: 

Up to 200 people can now attend audience-type community outdoor events, such as festivals, fireworks displays, rodeos and sporting events, and outdoor performances.
All public health measures, including physical distancing, remain in place. Seated outdoor events will still require the necessary space between families and cohorts within stadium-style seating.
The 100-person limit remains in place for other outdoor events and indoor seated/audience events.
The limit for indoor social gatherings, including wedding and funeral receptions and birthday parties, remains at 50 people maximum.
 UPDATE: The gathering limit has been cahnges in a few ways:

description:
Canada, NS, June 26th "Effective Friday, July 3, some gathering limits will increase. If a recognized business or organization is planning an event outdoors, 250 people can attend with physical distancing rules in place. For an indoor event, the limit is 50 per cent capacity to a maximum of 200, again with physical distancing.

Gatherings not run by a recognized business or organization, for example a family event in the backyard, are still subject to the 50-person maximum limit with physical distancing unless you’re in your close social group of 10." UPDATE: the gahtering limit has chaged in the following way: 
ffective Friday, July 3, some gathering limits will increase. If a recognized business or organization is planning an event outdoors, 250 people can attend with physical distancing rules in place. For an indoor event, the limit is 50 per cent capacity to a maximum of 200, again with physical distancing.

Gatherings not run by a recognized business or organization, for example a family event in the backyard, are still subject to the 50-person maximum limit with physical distancing unless you’re in your close social group of 10.

Canada, British Columbia March 16th "We are issuing a new order prohibiting all public gatherings of more than 50 people. This includes indoor and outdoor sporting events, conferences, meetings, religious gatherings and other similar events. " UPDATE: The original restriction was 50 people. The provincial health officer’s order on mass gatherings has been amended to limit the number of people in vacation accommodations, including for house, cabin, yurt and boat rentals, as well as hotel rooms. The number of people is limited to the capacity of the space, plus up to a maximum of five visitors.

Canada, Québec- As of the 23 April "the cancellation of indoor and outdoor festivals and cultural events planned in Québec until August 31, 2020." UPDATE: Festivals of 250 are allowed to happen in the province as of August 3. "The limit of 250 people must be respected at all times and that means organizers who push ahead with their events must be responsible for crowd control at entry and exit points." As well as making sure there is 2 meters between separate households at all times.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description: Canada, Yukon is now allowing indoor visits at Yukon's long-term care facilities as of August 19. There are still strict guidelines to follow: screening upon entry, mask and hand-sanitizer use, but contact will be permitted.

description: B.C.'s Ministry of Tourism, Arts and Culture said on August 25 that the province is moving to Phase 3 of its sports guidelines, allowing leagues and athletes to participate in organized sports, though cohorts of 10-100 people depending on the sport. Close physical proximity should still be minimized as much as possible, which mean game rules should be modified to keep participants at a safe distance, and organizers should limit the number and duration of contacts between participants when physical distancing isn't possible.

Larger leagues are being asked to create “mini-leagues” with a maximum of 60 players, not including coaching and officials.

description:
Organized indoor gatherings and events involving more than 50 persons may take place if the number of persons attending does not exceed 30% of the usual capacity of the premises, the premises where the gathering or
event is held is physically divided into separate areas which contain no more than 50 persons each, and persons in each area are prevented from
coming into close proximity with persons in another area during the gathering or event as well as when entering or leaving.

Canada, Manitoba is prohibiting people from assembling in an organized gathering or at an event involving more than 50 persons at an indoor place or more than 100 persons at an outdoor place. For certainty, this includes weddings, funerals, banquets, receptions and professional sporting activities.

Canada, Manitoba announced on October 26 that the maximum size of gatherings is reduced to five people. This applies to ceremonies, social events and informal gatherings. Gatherings involving more than five persons may take place if the number of persons attending does not exceed 30% of the usual capacity of the place or premises where the gathering is held.

Canada, Manitoba announced on October 26 that the maximum size of gatherings is reduced to five people. This applies to ceremonies, social events and informal gatherings. Gatherings involving more than five persons may take place if the number of persons attending does not exceed 30% of the usual capacity of the place or premises where the gathering is held. Update 19 November 2020: People are prohibited from assembling in a gathering of more than five people at any indoor or outdoor public place including the common areas of a multi-unit residence, with the exception of a health-care facility or critical business that adheres to health protection measures. UPDATE: people are prohibited from assembling in a gathering of more than five people at any indoor or outdoor public place including the common areas of a multi-unit residence, with the exception of a health-care facility or critical business that adheres to health protection measures.

Canada, O.N., 27 November 2020: Based on the latest data, the following public health regions will move from their current level in the framework to the following levels effective Monday, November 30, 2020 at 12:01 a.m.: Red-Control Windsor-Essex County Health Unit.
Canada, B.C. has set a temporary ban on in-person worship services.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description: In the Province of Alberta in Canada, it is recommended that sports and other extracurricular activities that involve physical contact be cancelled as an additional precaution as of March 13th.

Canada, Saskatchewan, March 13 "Effective immediately, people who have travelled outside the province in the previous 14 days or have acute respiratory or flu-like symptoms should avoid visiting long term care homes and hospitals."
Canada, NS, March 15th "Long term care facilities will be closed for visitors"

In Alberta, Canada, on March 16th it was announced that "The Provincial Court of Alberta and Court of Queen’s Bench are limiting operations. Visits to all Alberta provincial correctional facilities and young offender centres are suspended until further notice."

BC, Canada, March 16th "restrict visitors in long-term care to essential visits only. Essential visits include compassionate visits for end-of-life care and visits that support care plans for residents based on resident and family needs, for example, families who routinely visit to provide assistance with feeding or mobility."

Canada, NS, March 15 "Organizations and businesses must practise social distancing of two metres or six feet and keep gatherings below 150 or much smaller if possible. This applies to restaurants, bars, movie theatres and other gathering spots"

Canada, Ont, March 16 "In order to ensure a safe and secure environment for residents, the Chief Medical Officer of Health recently advised long-term care homes to only allow essential visitors—people visiting residents who are very ill or require end-of-life care—until further notice." UPDATE: Screening in long term care now changed to only essential visitors being allowed in long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: Canada, Sask, March 16 "The Chief Medical Health Officer orders that visitors to long-term care homes, hospitals, personal care homes and group homes are restricted to essential visitors only.  Essential visitors means immediate family visiting for compassionate reasons." UPDATE: Greater restriction on who can visit long term care facilities and hospitals

In Alberta Canada, as of March 20th, stronger restrictions are being put in place for visitors to long-term and seniors care facilities. Essential visitors will be restricted to a single individual who can be family, a friend, or a paid companion who provides care and companionship necessary for the well-being of the resident (physical and mental health) and/or a single designated visitor for a person who is dying, as long as only one visitor enters the facility at a time. Every visitor will undergo a health screening. UPDATE: More restricted visitation to long term care facilities

Canada, Ont, March 20 "Ontario is implementing amendments to Regulation 778 under the Ministry of Correctional Services Act to allow senior corrections officials to expand the use of temporary absences and for the Ontario Parole Board to use alternatives to in-person meetings." UPDATE: Ontario is implementing amendments to Regulation 778 under the Ministry of Correctional Services Act to allow senior corrections officials to expand the use of temporary absences and for the Ontario Parole Board to use alternatives to in-person meetings.

Canada, Manitoba, March 17, "Public health officials are recommending the immediate suspension of visitors in long-term care facilities across Manitoba.  Exceptions for compassionate reasons or end of life will be made on a case-by-case basis at the discretion of individual facility managers."

On May 20, long term care residents will be allowed up to 2 visitors for outdoor visits. UPDATE: On May 20, long term care residents will be allowed up to 2 visitors for outdoor visits.

Canada, Nova Scotia, March 22 "Any workplace or business that is not deemed essential can remain open as long as a two-metre or six-foot distance can be maintained. Additionally, all non-essential businesses must close, such as, personal service businesses, casinos, gyms, golf courses and private campgrounds must close." UPDATE: Business closures are extended and include more businesses
Canada, Manitoba, March 27 "require retailers to ensure separation of two metres between patrons in their facility"

Canada, Yukon, March 27 "Yukoners are urged to behave as if COVID-19 is already in their community. They should continue to keep a physical distance of two meters or six feet from each other and practice greater hygiene.
Yukoners are also strongly advised to avoid passing on inaccurate information they may hear about cases of infection. This creates additional anxiety at a time when many people are already struggling to maintain their mental health. "
Canada, Nunavut, April 1 "No visitors will be allowed at long term care facilities in Nunavut – Continuing Care Centres (CCCs) and Elders’ Homes."
Canada, PEI, April 1 "It is crucial during this time that Islanders practice physical distancing when going out for essential reasons. "

Canada, Nova Scotia, April 6 "Dr. Strang has directed licensed long-term care homes to follow measures to further prevent the introduction of the virus into these homes and to reduce its spread if introduced to the facility. The directive includes a number of provisions, including cleaning, monitoring of residents and staff, testing, and reporting. The directive and the measures were provided to the sector today and are effective immediately"

Canada, April 5, 2020 "Prohibit all commercial marine vessels with a capacity of more than 12 passengers from engaging in non-essential activities, such as tourism or recreation. These measures will remain in place until at least June 30, 2020.
Require ferries and essential passenger vessel operators to:
Immediately reduce by 50% the maximum number of passengers that may be carried on board (conduct half-load voyages) to support the two-metre physical distancing rule; or Implement alternative practices to reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19 (consistent with Public Health Agency of Canada guidelines) among passengers on board their vessels, such as keeping people in their vehicles, when feasible or enhanced cleaning and hygiene measures."
type_sub_cat: Restrictions ridership of other forms of public transportation (please include details in the text entry)

description: Canada, on April 7, 2020, the Public Health Agency of Canada is recommending citizens to wear non-medical face masks to help prevent possible COVID-19 transmission.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: Canada, Alberta, April 7 "Under an amended public health order, no visitors will be allowed unless a resident is dying or the visitor is essential for delivering care that cannot be delivered by staff." UPDATE: New restrictions for long term care facilities

Canada, Ontario, April 15 "The COVID-19 Action Plan: Long-Term Care Homes adds critical new measures to prevent further outbreaks and deaths from COVID-19 in long-term care homes, including:   

Aggressive Testing, Screening, and Surveillance: enhancing testing for symptomatic residents and staff and those who have been in contact with persons confirmed to have COVID-19; expanding screening to include more asymptomatic contacts of confirmed cases; and leveraging surveillance tools to enable care providers to move proactively against the disease.
Managing Outbreaks and Spread of the Disease: supporting long-term care homes with public health and infection control expertise to contain and prevent outbreaks; providing additional training and support for current staff working in outbreak conditions.
Growing our Heroic Long-Term Care Workforce: redeploying staff from hospitals and home and community care to support the long-term care home workforce and respond to outbreaks, alongside intensive on-going recruitment initiatives." UPDATE: Updated measures for long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description:
Canada, Quebec, April 15 "THAT in addition to the visits authorized by Ministerial Order 2020- 009 dated 23 March 2020, visits from a family caregiver to users lodged in facilities in institutions where a residential and long-term care centre is operated be authorized if the following conditions are met:
(1) the user was receiving support from the family caregiver before
13 March 2020 and that support is still necessary;
(2) the family caregiver
(a) understands the risks inherent in the visits;
(b) undertakes to respect the directives given by the institution and
the public health authorities; and
(c) received a negative COVID-19 screening result before the first
visit and shows no COVID-19 related symptoms;
(3) the director of public health for the region in which the institution
is situated has not ordered the visits suspended to protect the health of the
population" UPDATE: Update of the policy concerning visitors to long term care facilities

Canada, April 17, 2020 "Today, the Minister of Transport, the Honourable Marc Garneau, announced new measures requiring all air passengers to have a non-medical mask or face covering to cover their mouth and nose during travel. These measures come into effect at noon EDT on April 20, 2020 and will be in place until further notice. When travelling by air, travellers will be asked to cover their mouth and nose: at Canadian airport screening checkpoints, where the screeners cannot always keep two metres of separation between themselves and the traveller; when they cannot physically distance from others, or as directed by the airline employees; and when directed to do so by a public health order or public health official."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Canada, Nova Scotia, May 1 "Any workplace or business that is not deemed essential can remain open as long as a two-metre or six-foot distance can be maintained. Additionally, all non-essential businesses must close, such as personal service businesses, casinos, gyms, golf courses and private campgrounds must close. EXCEPT for Garden centres, nurseries and similar businesses can open sportfishing is permitted from shore or boat, but fishing derbies are not allowed people can attend boating, yacht or sailing clubs for the purpose of preparing boats for use; golf driving ranges can open, including those at golf clubs, but the course must remain closed; golf clubs can perform necessary maintenance and preparations for opening" UPDATE: Relaxing of restriction on some non-essential businesses
Canada, NB--Face masks will be mandatory in public places if social distancing is not possible beginning May 8.

Canada, Yukon, March 27 "Yukoners are urged to behave as if COVID-19 is already in their community. They should continue to keep a physical distance of two meters or six feet from each other and practice greater hygiene.
Yukoners are also strongly advised to avoid passing on inaccurate information they may hear about cases of infection. This creates additional anxiety at a time when many people are already struggling to maintain their mental health. "
UPDATE: Phase 1 - Double bubble”: close contact is allowed between members of 2 households. 10 people or fewer are allowed at indoor and outdoor social gatherings. UPDATE: Phase 1: “Double bubble" - close contact is allowed between members of 2 households. For both indoor and outdoor social gatherings, 10 people or fewer are allowed. Funerals and religious services may have relaxed restrictions subject to public health assessment.

Canada, PEI is reintroducing recreational activities with proper physical distancing guidance. 

"Recreational facilities allowed to re-open include:swimming pools, hot tubs and outdoor spas, arenas, recreational centres, bowling alleys, gyms and fitness facilities, yoga and pilates studios

Public spaces permitted to re-open include: art galleries, libraries, youth centres and community centres." This was announced on June 1 as part of the Phase 3 reopening.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
Canada, PEI, will permit visitors at long-term care facilities. "A maximum of two designated visitors will be allowed per resident." 
"All visitors will be required to maintain physical distancing — however, Dowling said officials realize some residents might have trouble keeping two metres apart. In those cases, she said visitors will be asked to wear non-medical masks or a face shield."
These efforts start June 1 as part of Phase 3 reopening. UPDATE: Long-term care visitations are now allowed as of June 1.

Canada, NS, June 5 "Effective June 5, most businesses required to close under the public health order can reopen. Businesses must follow protocols in the plan that is tailored to their sector. This includes following public health protocols to ensure physical distancing, increased cleaning and other protective measures for staff and customers.
The following can open if they are ready and choose to do so:
restaurants for dine-in, as well as takeout and delivery
bars, wineries, distilleries and taprooms" UPDATE: Restaurants and Bars may now open again

Canada, NS, June 10th "Effective Monday, June 15, visits can resume at long-term care facilities, provided they happen outdoors and visitors stay two metres or six feet away from residents and staff." UPDATE: Effective Monday, June 15, visits can resume at long-term care facilities, provided they happen outdoors and visitors stay two metres or six feet away from residents and staff.

Canada, Ontario "announced the gradual resumption of visits to long-term care homes, retirement homes, and other residential care settings. 

Long-term care homes will allow outdoor visits of one person per resident each week at a minimum. Retirement homes will resume indoor and outdoor visits in designated areas or resident suites when physical distancing can be maintained. Other residential care settings will be able to allow outdoor visits of two people at time. Physical distancing will be required for all visits."

These actions will begin June 18, 2020. UPDATE: People are now allowed to visit residents at long-term care homes, retirement centers, and other residential care facilities.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within a country

description: Canada, Québec: "As of June 22, a distance of 1 metre will be allowed between children age 16 and under," this policy is in place to allow children to interact in an easier way in relation to schooling.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
Canada, Manitoba, March 17, "Public health officials are recommending the immediate suspension of visitors in long-term care facilities across Manitoba.  Exceptions for compassionate reasons or end of life will be made on a case-by-case basis at the discretion of individual facility managers."

On the 22th. of June the porocintional goc of Manitoba Canada annouced: personal care homes (PCH) will soon begin permitting limited indoor visits for designated visitors. The indoor visits, to be approved by individual PCH care teams, will enable each resident to identify a short list of individuals who may visit during allotted times. UPDATE: personal care homes (PCH) will soon begin permitting limited indoor visits for designated visitors. The indoor visits, to be approved by individual PCH care teams, will enable each resident to identify a short list of individuals who may visit during allotted times.
On June 26th the government of Alberta, Canada Annouced that an indoor and outdoor events there should be social distancing of 2 meters.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: Canada, PEI, is now allowing indoor visitations for long-term care facilities as of June 26, 2020 as part of Phase 4 reopening. UPDATE: Long-term care homes can now have visitors.

Canada, NS, March 15 "Organizations and businesses must practise social distancing of two metres or six feet and keep gatherings below 150 or much smaller if possible. This applies to restaurants, bars, movie theatres and other gathering spots" UPDATE: On july 3rd. Gov of NS, Canada annouced that campgrounds can reopen for residents of the atlantic Canada provinces "Campers from all four Atlantic provinces can reserve and enjoy their spots at any of Nova Scotia’s 20 provincial campgrounds starting today, July 3.

With further easing of public health restrictions, the province will also open more than 300 additional campsites at provincial parks for bookings on Monday, July 6. Reservations will open at set times throughout the day. A schedule of which campgrounds open their reservations and at what time is posted on the Nova Scotia Provincial Parks website."

Canada, ONT: Masks are required inside of public places beginning July 7 as of 12:01 am in Ottawa, Toronto, Kingston, and other cities in the eastern region of Ontario.  There are exemptions to those who have to follow this order, including: children under 2, individuals with medical conditions that render wearing a mask unsafe, those who need assistance putting on/taking of a mask.
city: Ottawa, Kingston, Toronto, and other cities in the eastern region of Ontario.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: Québec is enforcing the "wearing a face covering, also known as a homemade mask, will be mandatory on public transit from July 13, 2020 for people age 12 and over. This obligation applies to buses, the subway, ferries, taxis, car services, etc."

Canada, ONT--July 15, the city council of Ottawa "approved a temporary by-law to make masks mandatory in indoor public spaces." "The by-law will be in place until Council’s next meeting on Wednesday, August 26, when it could be extended if warranted"
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all indoor spaces

description: Canada, Québec: "Masks or face coverings will be mandatory in all indoor public spaces across Quebec, beginning Saturday, July 18."

description:
Canada, NS, March 15th "Long term care facilities will be closed for visitors" UPDATE: On July 17th the gov of NS, Canada stated that "Changes to the province’s directive to long-term care homes will allow for more visitors outdoors, limited indoor visits, and some return to activities. Effective July 22, the following changes can be implemented by long-term care facilities:

both indoor and outdoor visits will be allowed with limited numbers of visitors and scheduled appointments. Residents and visitors must wear masks and observe physical distancing, except for limited physical contact like a hug
residents and staff can gather in groups of 10 or less for dining, recreation or socializing without physical distancing. Groups should remain consistent and visitors cannot join
sightseeing bus trips for groups of up to 10 people (including residents, staff and driver) are allowed. Residents and staff cannot get off the bus and thorough cleaning before and after each trip is required
licensed hair salons within long-term care homes can reopen to serve residents only"
Canada, Nova Scotia--"All passengers and drivers on public transportation are required to wear non-medical masks," as of July 24.

Canada, Nova Scotia-- Starting July 31, non medical masks will become mandatory in most indoor public places for all people above the age of two or without valid medical reason. UPDATE: The original mask requirements was for transportation services and people on public transportation but now its is mandatory in almost all indoor public places.

Canada, April 17, 2020 "Today, the Minister of Transport, the Honourable Marc Garneau, announced new measures requiring all air passengers to have a non-medical mask or face covering to cover their mouth and nose during travel. These measures come into effect at noon EDT on April 20, 2020 and will be in place until further notice. When travelling by air, travellers will be asked to cover their mouth and nose: at Canadian airport screening checkpoints, where the screeners cannot always keep two metres of separation between themselves and the traveller; when they cannot physically distance from others, or as directed by the airline employees; and when directed to do so by a public health order or public health official." UPDATE: On August 7, 2020, Transport Canada closed a loophole in the April 20, 2020 policy stating that all passengers who are unable to wear a face mask due to a medical condition must now present an official doctor's note stating that they are exempt from the rule, or they will be denied boarding.

description: Québec is enforcing the "wearing a face covering, also known as a homemade mask, will be mandatory on public transit from July 13, 2020 for people age 12 and over. This obligation applies to buses, the subway, ferries, taxis, car services, etc." UPDATE: The original mandatory mask requirement that started July 13 made masks mandatory from children over 12, starting August 24 the policy will extend to children 10 and over.
Canada, Manitoba is enforcing mandatory masks on Winnipeg Transit buses starting August 29. People not wearing masks while taking the bus could face a $100 fine for not following the new rules.

The transportation ministry of Canada announced October 29, 2020 that "cruise ships with overnight accommodations carrying more than 100 people continue to be prohibited from operating in Canadian waters. All other passenger vessels must continue following provincial, territorial, local and regional health authority guidance. Passenger vessels carrying more than 12 people continue to be prohibited from entering Arctic coastal waters, including Nunatsiavut, Nunavik and the Labrador Coast. Adventure-seeking pleasure craft also continue to be banned in Arctic waters" until at least February 28, 2021 in order to keep Canadians safe during the pandemic.
